subsection.heading: 1 Introduction: topic prominence
subsection.p: Topicalization in a broad sense refers to the formation of any syntactic construction containing a topic, whether it is derived by movement or base-generated. By Asian languages we mean those topic-prominent languages spoken in Asia. Not all the Asian languages are topic-prominent. Indonesian and Tagalog, for instance, are not, but some Asian languages that have a large population of speakers, notably Chinese and Japanese, are typically topic-prominent. According to Gundel's (1988) generalization from an investigation of 30 languages spoken in Asia and other continents of the world, all of them have syntactic topic constructions. Topics in all these languages share a great number of syntactic, semantic, and pragmatic properties. The topic occurs to the left of a full comment sentence. It is definite or generic and is characterized by shared familiarity to both the speaker and the hearer. The comment is a clause that follows the topic and says something about it. The relation between the topic and the comment is commonly characterized as ‘aboutness’ in the literature. Aboutness may be strict or loose across languages. The following subsections present properties characteristic of topic-prominent languages as against other languages and, particularly, properties that have played a role in linguistic theorizing.

subsection.heading: 1.1 Variety of topic structures
subsection.p: The term ‘topic prominence’ dates back to Li and Thompson (1976), in which a new typology is proposed to classify languages as (i) subject-prominent, (ii) topic-prominent, (iii) subject-prominent and topic-prominent, and (iv) neither subject-prominent nor topic-prominent. Topic-prominent languages use a greater variety of topic structures than other languages. The following illustrations are Korean, cited from Sohn (1994: 192–195):

(1)
Ku totwuk-un nay-ka cap-ass-ta.
the thief-TOP I-SUBJ catch-PAST-DEC 1
‘This thief, I caught.’

(2)
I sacin-un, nay-ka caknyen-ey i sacin-ul ccik-ess-eyo.
this photo-TOP I-SUBJ last-year-at this photo-OBJ take-PAST-POL
‘This photo, I look it last year.’

(3)
Hankwuk-to inkwu-ka manh-ta.
Korean-also population-SUBJ much-DEC
‘As for Korea also, the population is large.’

Korean is an SOV language. In (1), presumably the object has moved to the sentence-initial position, an operation called topicalization (in the narrow sense) in the literature. In (2), the initial NP is coreferential with another NP in the remaining part of the sentence. This is known as dislocation. Gundel's samples show that languages that are not topic-prominent also make use of topicalization and dislocation. What is coreferential with the topic may be an empty node, or a pronoun, or a full noun phrase. In topic-prominent languages, the coreferential constituent may be the partial or full repetition of the topic itself, as in the case of (2). Example (3) is typical of topic-prominent languages. It differs remarkably from the previous two sentences in that the initial NP is semantically related to the following part of the sentence but not coreferential with any empty node, pronoun, or full noun phrase in it. In other words, no constituent in the comment is more closely related to the topic than any other constituent. The comment as a whole is about the topic. Here are more examples from more languages, cited from Li and Thompson (1976: 462):

(4)
Neichang huo xingkui xiaofang-dui lai de kuai. Chinese
that fire fortunately fire-brigade come quick
‘That fire (topic), fortunately, the fire brigade came quickly.’

(5)
Gakkoo-wa buku-ga isogasi-kat-ta. Japanese
school-TOP I-SUBJ busy-PAST-DEC
‘School (topic), I was busy.’

(6)
Siban-in hakkjo-ga manso. Korean
now-TOP school-SUBJ many
‘The present time (topic), there are many schools.’
Such sentences are known in the literature as ‘Chinese-style’ topic structures, a term which originated in Chafe (1976), in contrast to ‘English-style’ topic structures.

Among the Chinese-style topic structures is a special construction, the so-called double subject construction or double nominative construction. 2 It is semantically characterized by a possessive relation, or a whole–part relation, or an inclusive relation between the first and the second NP. The following sentences are cited from Li and Thompson (1976: 468).

(7)
Ho ō na-qhô yì ve yò. Lahu
elephant TOP nose long PRT DEC
‘Elephants (topic), noses are long.’

(8)
Neike shu yezi da. Chinese
that tree leaves big
‘That tree (topic), leaves are big.’

(9)
Sakana-wa tai-ga oisii. Japanese
fish-TOP red snapper-SUBJ tasty
‘Fish (topic), red snapper is tasty.’

(10)
Pihengki-nin 747-ka khi-ta. Korean
Airplane-TOP 747-SUBJ big-DEC
‘Airplanes (topic), the 747 is big.’

The elephant is the possessor and the nose is the possessed in (7). The leaves are part of the whole tree in (8). Red snapper is a hyponym and fish is its super-ordinate term in (9). 747 is a subset of airplanes in (10).

subsection.heading: 1.2 Topic marking
subsection.p: Topic-prominent languages tend to mark topics just as subject-prominent languages tend to mark subjects. Particularly, OV languages like Japanese and Korean use special postpositions to mark a wide variety of expressions used as topics. The following examples are Korean, cited from Gundel (1988: 217):

(11)
John-nin i salam-lil manna-ass-ta.
John-TOP this man-OBJ meet-PAST-DEC
‘John (topic), met this man.’

(12)
I salam-nin John-ka manna-ass-ta.
this man-TOP John-SUBJ meet-PAST-DEC
‘This man, John met.’

(13)
Suyeng-nin Waikiki-ka coh-ta.
swimming-TOP Waikiki-SUBJ good-DEC
‘(As for) swimming, Waikiki is good.’

(14)
Ecey-nin John-ka naksicil-lil ka-ass-ta.
yesterday-TOP John-SUBJ fishing-OBJ go-PAST-DEC
‘Yesterday, John went fishing.’

(15)
San-ey-nin namu-ka manh-ta.
mountain-at-TOP tree-SUBJ many-DEC
‘At the mountain, there are many trees.’

(16)
San-ey ka-1 ttay-ey-nin moca-lil ssi-la.
mountain-to go time-at-TOP hat-OBJ wear-IMP
‘When you go to the mountain, wear a hat.’

What is marked as a topic can be a subject, an object, a nominalized VP, a temporal expression, a locative expression, a clause, etc. With a topic marker in place, whether the sentence-initial expression is a topic or not is uncontroversial in Japanese and Korean. 3 In Chinese, topic marking is optional and in most of the Chinese dialects particles that are used to mark topics can also be used for other purposes, for instance, as sentence-final markers. This is one of the reasons why there are more controversies in the literature related to the structure and interpretation of Chinese topic constructions and also an important reason why more Chinese examples will be used in the remaining sections.

subsection.heading: 2 Topic structures containing a gap bound to the topic
subsection.p: This section addresses topic structures that contain a gap interpreted as coreferential with the topic. It considers the syntactic and semantic conditions on the relation between the topic and the gap.

subsection.heading: 2.1 Movement
subsection.p: A question naturally arises: do such topic structures involve movement? Opinions differ among Chinese linguists. Some are in favor of the transformational hypothesis (TH) and others are in favor of the base generation hypothesis (BGH).

The following Chinese and English sentences are structurally so parallel that it seems reasonable to assume that a Chinese topic structure containing a gap involves movement just as its English counterpart does, whether it is straight-forward movement of an overt expression from the comment into the topic node, or more sophisticated movement of an abstract element along the lines of Chomsky's (1977b) analysis of wh-movement:

(17)
a. Naben shu, ta na-le. Chinese
that book he take-ASP
‘That book, he took.’
b. Ta na-le neiben shu.

(18)
a. That book, he took. English
b. He took that book.
However, there is an underlying difference. While the English sentence in (19) is not grammatical, its Chinese counterpart in (20) is:
(19) *He took.
(20) Ta na-le.

Most of the Chinese verbs that are transitive in meaning can occur without an object. 4 The small number of transitive verbs that require an object cannot appear without an object even in topic structures. Yuan (1996) emphasizes the impossibility of object drop in topicalization. Below are some Chinese illustrations:

(21)
a. Xin Zhengce hui fanrong jinrong shichang.
new policy will boom money market
‘The new policy will cause the money market to boom.’
b. *Jinrong shichang, xin zhengce hui fanrong.
money market new policy will boom
‘The money market, the new policy will cause to boom.’

(22)
a. Tade hua wennuan-le womende xin.
his words warmed our hearts
‘His words warmed our hearts.’
b. *Womende xin, tade hua wennuan-le.
our hearts, his words warmed
‘Our hearts, his words warmed.’

Even though it is logically possible that the topicalized expression undergoes movement and that the remaining part of the sentence must be grammatical by itself in some languages, 5 the arguments in support of the movement analysis for English sentences like (18a) on the basis of the requirement on subcategorization do not apply to Chinese sentences. The crucial test of the movement hypothesis is, of course, to see whether a topic can be related to a gap in islands such as complex noun phrases and sentential subjects.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Island effects
subsection.p: Following Chomsky (1977b), those in favor of the TH assume that the topic is base-generated in its surface position and that topicalization involves the movement of an abstract element from an argument position to a position immediately adjacent to the topic. The evidence presented in support of this hypothesis is that such abstract movement is subject to island constraints. Examples such as (23) have been provided in the literature to show that it observes Subjacency and attempts made to explain away apparent counter-examples such as (24):

(23)
*Neige reni, [IP[NP[IP ti
kanjian tj] de xueshengj] lai-le]. Chinese
that man see MOD student come-ASP
‘The student who saw that man came.’

(24)
??Neiben shui [IP[NP[IP
Lisi mei kan ti]] zhen qiguai. Chinese
that book not read real strange
‘That Lisi didn't read that book is really strange.’

(23) illustrates the effects of the Complex Noun Phrases Constraint. Movement out of the relative clause 6 is blocked because it crosses the boundaries of NP and IP. (24) is acceptable, 7 even though the topic seems to have been moved out of the sentential subject. It has been suggested that (24) be assigned the structure in (25), where topicalization occurs within the inner clause and therefore does not violate the Subjacency Condition:
(25) [IP[NP[Neiben shui [IP Lisi mei kan ti]]] zhen qiguai].
Those in favor of the BGH argue against the transformational approach on the basis of the following counter-evidence:

(26)
[CP
Zheben shui [IP [NP[IP ej
du guo ei
de] renj] bu duo]]. Chinese
this book read ASP MOD people not many
‘This book, there are not many people who read (it).’

(27)
[CP
Zhexie shi [IP
wo juede [IP [IP
ta shou e] bu heshi]]]. Chinese
these things I think he says not proper
‘These things, I think it is not proper for him to say.’

Like (23), (26) contains a relative clause; nevertheless, the topic can be coreferential with the empty site represented by e across the boundaries of NP and IP. The difference in acceptability between (23) and (26) will be dealt with in section 2.5. Like (24), (27) contains a sentential subject. To rule out the possibility of assigning a structural description similar to (25) as has been proposed for (24), one can embed the sentence one clause further. It turns out that the topic in the leftmost position of the matrix clause can still be associated with a position inside the sentential subject embedded one or even more clauses down.
In (28) the topic is also coreferential with an empty site within the sentential subject:

(28)
Zhege wenti [wo xiang [ni zheyang huida e] hen deti]. Chinese
this question I think you this-way reply very appropriate
‘This question, I think it is very appropriate for you to answer in this way.’
If movement is always subject to the Subjacency Condition, then the evidence compels one to conclude that topicalization in Chinese does not involve movement. 8
We now leave Chinese and turn to Japanese for the rest of this subsection. It was observed as early as Kuno (1973b) that the topic can be related to an empty site in islands:

(29)
Sono syooneni-wa [IP [NP ei ej
kawaigatte ita] inuj]-ga sinde simatta.
that boy-TOP fond-of was dog-SUBJ dying ended up
‘Speaking of that boy, the dog that he was fond of died.’

(30)
Sono sinsii-wa [NP [IP eI ej
kite iru] yoohukuj]-ga yogorete iru.
that gentleman-TOP wearing is suit-SUBJ dirty is
‘Speaking of that gentleman, the suit that he is wearing is dirty.’
Later, Hasegawa (1981) points out that the following sentences are somewhat less acceptable, possibly due to their violation of Subjacency:

(31)
??Ano- hon-wa John-ga [NP [IP e
kaita] hito]-ni aitagatte iru rasii.
that book-TOP John-SUBJ wrote person-to want-to-meet seem
‘Speaking of that book, it seems that John wants to meet the person who wrote it.’

(32)
?Russell-wa John-ga [NP [IP e
atta koto-ga aru] hito]-o mituketa rasii.
Russell-TOP John-SUBJ met fact-SUBJ have person-OBJ found seem
‘Speaking of Russell, it seems that John found a person who had actually met him.’
Comparing (31) and (32) with their scrambling counterparts (33) and (34), Saito (1987) believes that the marginality of the former is due to a constraint weaker than Subjacency:

(33)
?*Ano hon-o John-ga [NP [IP t
kaita] hito]-ni aitagatte iru rasii.
that book-OBJ John-SUBJ wrote person-to want-to-meet seem
‘It seems that John wants to meet the person who wrote that book.’

(34)
?*Russell-ni John-ga [NP [IP e
atta koto-ga aru] hito]-o mituketa rasii.
Russell-to John-SUBJ met fact-SUBJ have person-OBJ found seem
‘It seems that John found a person who had actually met Russell.’
But Saito observes that topicalization of a prepositional phrase in (35d) is more difficult than topicalization of an object in (35b) or a locative noun phrase in (35c):

(35)
a. John-ga [NP [IP
Pekin-ni itta koto-ga aru] hito]-o mituketa rasii.
John-SUBJ Beijing-to went fact-SUBJ have person-OBJ found seem
‘It seems that John found a person who has been to Beijing.’
b.
??Pekin-wa John-ga [NP [IP e itta koto-ga aru] hito]-o mituketa rasii Pekin-TOP.
c.
?*Pekin-ni John-ga [NP [IP t itta koto-ga aru] hito]-o mituketa rasii Pekin-to.
d. *Pekin-ni-wa John-ga [NP [IP e itta koto-ga aru] hito]-o mituketa rasii Pekin-to-TOP.

The former may be regarded as a case of island violation. But Saito notes that even the topic in situ is marginally acceptable in these sentences and so judgment is too subtle to be fully reliable. Later, Haig (1996) argues that the reason why (35c) and (35d) are not acceptable is that there is no logical relationship between the topicalized noun phrase and the comment clause. It is more difficult to interpret a comment as being about ‘to Beijing’ than about ‘Beijing’ alone.
On the whole, there seem to be fewer proponents of the movement approach to topicalization among Japanese linguists than among their Chinese colleagues.

subsection.heading: 2.3 Generalized Control Rule
subsection.p: We now return to Chinese. To maintain that topicalization obeys Subjacency, Huang (1984) proposes a solution to problems that arise from the grammaticality of sentences such as (36), structurally similar to (26):

(36)
Zhangsan, [[ e xihuan e de] ren] hen duo. Chinese
Zhangsan like MOD people very many
‘Zhangsan, people who he likes are many.’
‘Zhangsan, people who like him are many.’

His solution makes use of Chomsky's (1982: 35) view on the functional determination of empty categories (EC). Whether an EC is derived by movement or base-generated, its interpretation is determined by its role in derivations and representations. An EC is a variable if it is in an A-position and is locally A′-bound. An EC that is not a variable is a pronominal if it is free or locally A-bound by an antecedent with an independent theta-role. The two ECs in (36) can be categorized in this light. Huang further proposes a rule of interpretation for empty pronominals, which he calls the Generalized Control Rule: co-index an empty pronominal with the closest nominal element. 9 With it he derives the two readings of (36) as follows.

In the first reading, the empty subject starts out as a pronominal. It is co-indexed with the closest nominal element, i.e., Zhangsan. Then it converts itself into a variable. The empty object is co-indexed with the head of the relative clause ren.

In the second reading, it is assumed that the empty object is moved to a topic position within the relative clause, a local movement that does not violate Subjacency. Then it can be co-indexed with the closest nominal element Zhangsan in accordance with the Generalized Control Rule, giving rise to the following structure:
(37) Zhangsan, [[ei ej xihuan ti de] renj] hen duo.
The same analysis applies to (26) and can thus account for its grammaticality and interpretation despite its apparent violation of Subjacency.

subsection.heading: 2.4 Resumptive pronoun
subsection.p: The solution described in the preceding section works for cases where the relative clause is contained in the subject but not for those where it is contained in the object. (38) is an illustration of the latter:

(38)
Neiben shui, [wo renshi hen duo [[ej kan-bu-dong ei de] renj]]. Chinese
that book I know very many cannot-understand MOD person
‘That book, I know many people who can't read [it].’

In this sentence the object rather than the subject is relativized. The topic is associated with an empty category in a complex noun phrase that functions as the object. Suppose the empty object moves into the topic position of the relative clause: the Generalized Control Rule would predict that it should derive its content from the subject of the root clause wo, i.e., its closest nominal element. Since the topic is more remote than the subject, it should not be able to bind the empty object.

Another solution has been proposed by arguing that the empty object bound to the topic is actually a phonetically unrealized resumptive pronoun. In most cases Chinese pronouns take animate NPs but not inanimate NPs as antecedents. The contrast is clear in (39a, b):

(39)
a. Neige jiahuoi, [wo renshi hen duo [ej bu xihuan tai
de renj]].
that fellow I know very many not like him MOD person
‘That fellow, I know many people who don't like him.’
b. *Neiben shui, [wo renshi hen duo [ej kan-bu-dong tai
de renj]].
that book I know very many cannot-understand it MOD person
‘That book, I know many people who can't read it.’

So there is no alternative but to make the resumptive pronoun in (39b) empty, resulting in (38). In other words, (38) is a case of dislocation except that the resumptive pronoun has to be null for an independent reason. Once a resumptive pronoun is present, island conditions are simply not relevant. Similarly, violation of the Sentential Subject Constraint in (27), repeated below as (40), may also be more apparent than real for the same reason. Zhexie shi, too, is an inanimate NP and thus cannot but bind an empty resumptive pronoun.

(40)
[CP
Zhexie shi [IP
wo juede [IP [IP
ta shou e] bu heshi]]]. Chinese
these things I think he says not proper
‘These things, I think it is not proper for him to say.’

The resumptive pronoun hypothesis has a difficulty: even an animate NP used as the topic can bind into an island. Though no such examples were documented in the earlier literature, they are not at all difficult to construct for Chinese:

(41)
a. Zhege wanpi de haizii
[wo zhao-bu-dao [ej yuanyi shouyang tai
de renj]].
this naughty MOD child I can't-find willing adopt him MOD person
‘This naughty child, I can't find a person who is willing to adopt him.’
b. Zhege wanpi de haizii [wo zhao-bu-dao [ej yuanyi shouyang ei de renj]].

(42)
a. Zhewei houxuanreni
[women zai ge di jian-dao-le wushu [ej yonghu tai
de renj]].
this candidate we PREP every place see-ASP numerous support him MOD person
‘This candidate, we saw numerous people who supported him everywhere.’
b. Zhewei houxuanreni [women zai ge di jian-dao-le wushu [ej yonghu ei de renj]].

These sentences are structurally identical to (38) except that the topics are animate NPs. Both the (a)-forms and the (b)-forms are grammatical. Since animate NPs can be the antecedents of overt pronouns in Chinese, there is no compelling reason for the resumptive pronouns to take a zero form. Therefore the empty objects in (41b) and (42b) must be either empty pronominals or variables. If they are identified as pronominals, they undermine the assumption made in Huang (1984) that objects can never be pro. If, on the other hand, they are variables bound to the topics, Subjacency is violated. 10

subsection.heading: 2.5 Syntactic and semantic conditions
subsection.p: Researchers are still looking for more convincing evidence of island effects. Meanwhile topic structures in topic-prominent languages are found to be subject to other syntactic and semantic conditions. Among them is the well-known aboutness condition, which requires that the topicalized NP must be characterized by the rest of the sentence. See Takami and Kamio (1994), among others.

Xu and Langendoen (1985) postulate the following condition on topic structures in Chinese: the comment itself must be well-formed. This condition is not imposed on topicalization in English. On the contrary, to make the comment clause grammatical, the fronted topic must be recovered at its source position. 11 Since then this postulation has been reviewed by a number of researchers. It has been found to be a necessary but not a sufficient condition. Various additional conditions have been discovered.
Huang (1992) observes that the ungrammaticality of the (b)-sentences below is not predicted by the above generalization:

(43)
a. Ta toutoude jiao ni shagua. Chinese
he stealthily call you fool
‘He secretly calls you fool.’
b. *Shagua, ta toutou de jiao ni.

(44)
a. Wo quan ta manpao. Chinese
I advise him jog
‘I advised him to jog.’
b. *Manpao, wo quan ta.

The comment clauses in (43b) and (44b) are well-formed or can be made well-formed with minor revision. Huang points out that problem arises if the restriction on topicalization is formulated only in terms of syntactic categories. The ungrammaticality of (43b) and (44b) can be successfully treated by functionally based theories, but not by structurally based theories. Adopting the theory of Functional Uncertainty proposed by Kaplan and Zaenen (1989) in the framework of Lexical Functional Grammar, he postulates the constraint as follows: GFs (i.e., grammatical functions) of XCOMP (i.e., open complements of any categories) cannot be topicalized.
The functional theory is claimed to be able to account for the contrast in grammaticality shown in (45) as well:

(45)
a. Ni yijing biye le, wo zhidao. Chinese
you already graduate ASP I know
‘That you have already graduated, I know.’
b. *Ni yijing biye le, wo yiwei.
you already graduate ASP I think

The difference cannot be expressed in terms of syntactic categorization, since in both cases what is topicalized is S′, i.e., CP. LFG labels the embedded clause in (45a) as OBJ2 (i.e., second object) and the one in (45b) as COMP (i.e., sentential argument representing a propositional role) respectively. The latter is excluded from a legal topic construction.

Yuan (1996) lists a wide range of constructions that resist topicalization, including those discussed in Huang (1992). Although he does not propose a theory to account for the facts, he also shows that the grammaticality of the comment clause is subject to various other conditions.
Jiang (1991a, 1991b) calls attention to another constraint on topicalization, which is shown in the embedded clause following certain verbs:

(46)
a. Zhangsan xiangxin [Lisi qu kan le Wangwu]. Chinese
Zhangsan believe Lisi go see ASP Wangwu
‘Zhangsan believes that Lisi has gone to see Wangwu.’
b. Zhangsan xiangxin [Wangwu, Lisi qu kan le].
Zhangsan believe that Wangwu, Lisi has gone to see

(47)
a. Zhangsan xihuan [Lisi qu kan Wangwu]. Chinese
Zhangsan like Lisi go see Wangwu
‘Zhangsan likes Lisi to go to see Wangwu.’
b. *Zhangsan xihuan [Wangwu, Lisi qu kan].

Topicalization can take place in embedded clauses following verbs like xiangxin, but not in those following verbs like xihuan. Jiang distinguishes the two types of complement clause by labeling them saturated clause (SAS) and unsaturated clause (NSS) respectively. SAS expands into XP S (i.e., topic and comment) while NSS expands into NP VP (i.e., subject and predicate).
Embedded topicalization in Japanese is studied in Maki et al. (1999). They show that it is found in the complement clauses of bridge verbs but not in the complement clauses of factive verbs:

(48)
a. John-wa [kono hon-wa Mary-ga yonda to] sinziteiru. Japanese
John-TOP this book-TOP Mary-SUBJ read COMP believe
‘John believes that this book, Mary read.’
b. John-wa [kono hon-*wa Mary-ga yonda no]-o kookaisiteiru.
John-TOP this book-TOP Mary-SUBJ read COMP-ACC regret
‘John regrets that this book, Mary read.’

They posit that Japanese embedded topicalization involves IP adjunction and LF movement to the embedded COMP. The complement clause following a bridge verb is L-marked and that following a factive verb is not. Adjunction to a non-L-marked head is prohibited.

Not all constraints on the relation between the topic and what it binds are syntactic. For instance, what is responsible for the contrast in acceptability between (49a) and (49b) (given above as (26))?

(49)
a. ??Zheben shui [S [NP [S ej
du guo ei de] renj] lai le. Chinese
this book read ASP MOD man come ASP
*‘This book, I think the man who read came.’
b. Zheben shui [S [NP [S ej
du guo ei de] renj] bu duo].
this book read ASP MOD people not many
‘There are not many people who read this book.’

Some researchers attribute the difference in acceptability to the contrast between specificity and non-specificity of the relativized NPs. The NP du guo de ren is understood as non-specific in (49b), but specific in (49a). The sentence in (49a) is less acceptable because of a semantic principle like the ‘name constraint’ of Guéron (1980), which prohibits a name (i.e., a complete referring expression) from containing a variable. 12

In (50a, b) a lexical pronoun, rather than an empty category, is anaphorically related to the topic. But similarly, the result is acceptable if the NP containing the pronoun is non-specific, but less acceptable if it is specific: 13

(50)
a. Zhege qiangdao wo xiang neng zhuazhu ta de ren shi ge yingxiong. Chinese
this robber I think can catch he MOD man be a hero
‘This robber, I think anyone who can catch him is a hero.’
b. ??Zhege qiangdao wo xiang zhuazhu ta de ren lai le.
this robber I think catch he MOD man come ASP
‘This robber, I think the man who caught him came.’

subsection.heading: 3 Topic structures containing no element bound to the topic
subsection.p: This section addresses topic structures that do not contain a gap or an overt element interpreted as coreferential with the topic. As mentioned in section 1.1, they are known as ‘Chinese-style’ topic structures, involving neither topicalization (in the narrow sense) nor dislocation. We begin with Japanese and Korean and then move on to Chinese.

subsection.heading: 3.1.1 Japanese
subsection.p: It is almost universally agreed by Japanese linguists that topics like those in (9) (repeated here as (51a)) and (51b), which do not bind an empty site, are generated in situ, following Kuno (1973b, 1973c):

(51)
a. Sakana-wa tai-ga oisii.
fish-TOP red snapper-SUBJ tasty
‘Speaking of fish, red snapper is tasty.’
b. Hana-wa sakura-ga ii.
flower-TOP cherry blossoms-SUBJ good
‘Speaking of flowers, cherry blossoms are the best.’

However, Kuroda (1986, 1992) proposes an alternative analysis. He was the first to apply the tranformational-generative approach to the analysis of Japanese topicalization, in Kuroda (1965). Kuroda (1986, 1992) claims that the following (a)-sentences (cited from Kuno 1973c) are derived from the (b)-sentences and the latter from the (c)-sentences, even though some (b)- or (c)-sentences sound less natural:

(52)
a. Sakana-wa tai-ga yoi.
fish-TOP red snapper-SUBJ good
‘As for fish, the red snapper is good.’
b. ??Sakana-ga tai-ga yoi.
fish-SUBJ red snapper-SUBJ good
c. ??Sakana-no tai-ga yoi.
fish-POSS red snapper-SUBJ good

(53)
a. Buturigaku-wa syuusyoku-ga taihen da.
physics-TOP employment-SUBJ hard DEC
‘As for physics, employment is hard.’
b. Buturigaku-ga syuusyoku-ga taihen da.
physics-SUBJ employment-SUBJ hard DEC
c. ??Buturigaku de syuusyoku-ga taihen da.
physics with employment-SUBJ hard DEC

Kuroda observes that many wa-phrases alternate with ga-phrases, and argues that those that do not are not genuine topics but vocatives, etc., and therefore should be excluded from consideration. In contrast, wa-phrases that bind empty sites do not alternate with ga-phrases. So his hypothesis is that all topic phrases are generated in an argument or adjunct position within IP. They may move to an A′-position dominated by CP. Movement takes place prior to Linear Case Marking. Thus phrases within IP are assigned ga and those outside IP are assigned wa (Kuroda 1992: 286–287).

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Korean
subsection.p: Choe (1995) argues that in Korean, even topics that apparently do not bind any element in the comment are derived by an operation called Topic Movement. There are several different types of Topic Movement. In some topic structures the topic has a whole–part relation with another NP in the comment. Earlier, Choe (1986) assumes that such a construction, as exemplified in (54a), is the result of Possessor Raising. Its surface structure is (54b):

(54)
a. Khokkili-nun [kho-ka] kil-ta.
elephant-TOP nose-SUBJ long-DEC
‘In speaking of elephants, noses are long.’
b. Khokkili-nuni [ti kho-ka] kil-ta.

In some other topic structures, the topic is also semantically related to another NP in the comment, but it is not a part–whole relation. The topic in (55a) is an example. Choe assumes that (55a) is derived from (55b) by a movement process which preposes the nun-phrase to the sentence-initial position: 14

(55)
a. Hyangki-nun cangmi-ka choeko-ta.
fragrance-TOP rose-SUBJ best-DEC
‘In speaking of the fragrance (of flowers), roses are best.’
b. Cangmi-ka hyangki-nun choeko-ta.

subsection.heading: 3.1.3 Chinese
subsection.p: In the early days of transformational grammar, it was proposed in Thompson (1973) that (56a) is derived from (56b), not usable as a surface form:

(56)
a. Shuiguo, wo xihuan pingguo.
fruit I like apples
‘As for fruit, I like apples.’
b. *Wo xihuan pingguo shuiguo.

Since then linguists seem to have come to agree that the topic in (56a) is base-generated, and that so is the topic in the so-called double subject construction or double nominative construction in (57):

(57)
Shuiguo, pingguo zui haochi.
fruit apple most tasty
‘As for fruit, the apple is most tasty.’

Shyu (1995) proposes distinguishing two kinds of topics, assuming that a topic that does not bind a gap is base-generated in an IP-adjunction site, while a topic that does is moved to the Spec position of another maximal projection called TopP. She renames the former ‘major subject’, leaving the term ‘topic’ for the latter exclusively. A major subject can be raised to Spec TopP later.

subsection.heading: 3.2 Topic or not topic?
subsection.p: Linguists who do not believe that topic structures in Chinese, Japanese, and Korean are radically different from those in English and other European languages have two strategies to reduce or eliminate the diversity. One is to argue that any topic is derived by movement and thus always binds a gap. The other is to argue that the sentence-initial expression that does not bind a gap is, in fact, not a topic but something else; for instance, the subject of the sentence. Since a topic is unequivocally case-marked in Japanese and Korean as distinctive from a subject, the former strategy is more reasonable. Chinese does not require the use of overt markers to mark topics, so the latter strategy is plausible. There have always been Chinese grammarians who prefer to take the sentence-initial expression to be a possessive NP with a zero possessive marker, or as an adverbial with a zero form of preposition, or as a subject followed by a clausal predicate. A solution widely accepted by traditional grammarians (e.g., Chao 1968; Lü 1986) is calling the first NP ‘main subject’ or ‘major subject’ and the second one ‘minor subject’. While the minor subject takes a VP as its predicate, the major subject takes a clause as its predicate, thus doing away with the troublesome term ‘topic’ completely. 15
Shi (2000), based on Shi (1992), is a recent representative of the traditional reductionist view, this time in formalist terminology. His claim is summarized as follows:

(58) A topic is invariably related to a syntactic position in the comment and a comment is invariably an open sentence containing a gap or a resumptive pronoun coreferential with the topic. (Shi 2000: 388)

In this view every topic must be syntactically licensed. It cannot be merely semantically related to the comment as a whole, a relation known in the literature as aboutness. This is a strong claim. If it is true, then there is no significant structural difference between topic-prominent languages and other languages, though the former statistically use topic structures more often than the latter. To maintain (58), Shi adopts a piecemeal solution. He lists six types of ‘dangling topics’ and argues that in each case either there is a hidden gap or a resumptive pronoun in the comment from which the sentence-initial element originated, or it is not a genuine topic. There are other types of Chinese-style topic structures as well, including the well-known double nominative construction represented by (8) and (57), and those that have no particular names, such as the topic structure in (56). To fulfill his objective, Shi must eliminate each and every one of them as well. This is an arduous task.

To refute (58) is an equally arduous task. Pan and Hu (2001, 2002) take a semantic approach, providing counter-evidence to Shi's (2000) treatment of all the six types of topic structures. In their analysis, a topic may be semantically licensed or syntactically licensed. What follows the topic may semantically be interpreted as an open predicate without a syntactic gap or resumptive pronoun. Sections 3.2.1 and 3.2.2 present their debate on two representatives of the six types listed in Shi (2000). For further discussion on the other types, see the appendix to this chapter (section 5).

subsection.heading: 3.2.1 Topic or subject?
subsection.p: Shi (2000) provides the two sentences in (59) and (60) to illustrate a special case of the double nominative construction:

(59)
Tamen, wo kan ni, ni kan wo. Chinese
they I look you you look me
‘They look at each other.’

(60)
Tamen, da yu chi xiao yu. Chinese
they big fish eat small fish
‘They act according to the rule of the jungle.’

The sentence-initial pronoun tamen represents a set, and the NPs that follow, wo, ni or da yu, xiao yu, are members of the set. These two sentences differ from other Chinese-style topic structures in that, as Shi points out, the clauses that follow the pronouns are idioms, in which the lexical items are not freely changeable and their order is fixed. He argues that the pronouns are, in fact, subjects 16 that take idioms as their predicates. This analysis is supported by the fact that the adverb zhuanmen (specially), which always follows the subject but never precedes it, appears between the pronoun and the idiom:

(61)
Tamen, zhuanmen da yu chi xiao yu. Chinese
they specially big fish eat small fish
‘They are doing nothing but acting according to the rule of the jungle.’
Pan and Hu challenge Shi in three respects: the definition of idiom, the assignment of a thematic role, and the adverbial placement test.

Shi's argument is based on two implicit assumptions: (i) an idiom can be the predicate of a sentence, even though it is in the form of a clause, complete with a subject of its own; (ii) a clause that is not an idiom cannot be a predicate. So the distinction between an idiom and an ordinary clause is important. Pan and Hu call readers’ attention to sentences like (62):

(62)
Tamen, zuotian xiawu Xiao Zhang mei lai, Xiao Li ye mei lai. Chinese
they yesterday afternoon Xiao Zhang not come Xiao Li also not come
‘Yesterday afternoon, of the two people, Xiao Zhang didn't come and Xiao Li didn't come, either.’

This sentence is structurally similar to Shi's examples in (59) and (60). It begins with a plural pronoun followed by one or more clauses. The pronoun represents a set and the subject of the clause represents its members. What follows the pronoun in (62) is obviously not an idiom, because it contains randomly selected proper names and an adverbial referring to specific time. If any complete clause, whether or not an idiom, can be analyzed as the predicate of the sentence, then it just repeats the solution proposed by traditional Chinese grammarians involving major subjects and minor subjects. If only an idiomatized clause can be the predicate, one would like to know why one should give idioms special consideration and how to analyze non-idiom clauses like the one in (62).

Even if one is ready to take any clause as a predicate, there is a problem in assigning a thematic role to the sentence-initial pronoun. If it is a topic, according to Shi (2000: 405), it “always depends on an element inside the comment for its thematic role.” If it is a subject, it should have an independent thematic role. Pan and Hu wonder how the pronouns in (59–62) can get a thematic role. The predicate in the form of a clause is syntactically saturated and therefore does not have an extra thematic role for the sentence-initial pronoun.
The adverbial placement test is also problematic and unreliable. Pan and Hu provide an example in which the adverb zhuanmen appears after an uncontroversial topic. 17
Pan and Hu (2001, 2002) formally formulate their semantic licensing condition for such topic-comment structures as follows:
(63) &lgr;P&lgr;Z ⊆ things &lgr;x&lgr;y [x∈Z & y∈Z & P(x, y)]

After applying (63) to the first clause in (59), they get C = &lgr;Z [ni′∈Z & wo′∈Z & kan′ (ni′, wo′)]. Since C is an open predicate, it can take the topic tamen as its argument, and thus the topic in question is licensed by the open semantic predicate C. (There is a process of conjunction between the two clauses in (58). Actually, the topic is combined with the conjoined clauses, which have the semantic representation &lgr;Z [ni′ ∈Z & wo′ ∈Z & kan′(ni′, wo′) & kan′ (wo′, ni′)].

subsection.heading: 3.2.2 With or without a gap?
subsection.p: Another type of Shi's ‘dangling topic’ is represented by (64), a classic example that first appeared in Chao (1968) and was later cited repeatedly in the literature (e.g., in slightly different form, as (4) above): 18

(64)
Nachang huo, xingkui xiaofangdui lai-de kuai. Chinese
that fire fortunately fire-brigade came fast
‘That fire, fortunately the fire brigade came quickly.’

Shi admits that nachang huo may be taken as a topic but argues that it is so because it is related to an empty position in a sentence which is understood by the speaker and the hearer. 19 What he means is that there should be a phonologically unrealized subsequent sentence which contains a gap anaphoric to the topic. Shi (2000: 393) puts forward the following sentence as subsequent to (64), containing an empty subject marked by e:

(65)
Buran e jiu hui shao-si bu shao ren. Chinese
otherwise
really will burn-die not-few people
‘Otherwise (it) would have killed many people.’

Earlier, Shi (1992: 109) characterized sentences such as (64) as ‘incomplete’. The addition of a subsequent sentence makes it a complete discourse and provides an empty subject position. Yuan (1996) independently proposes exactly the same solution.

Although addition of a subsequent sentence may make the discourse complete or more complete, whatever ‘complete’ means, there is no guarantee that it always contains a gap. For instance, the subsequent sentence can be (66) instead of (65):

(66)
Buran women dou hui sidiao. Chinese
otherwise we all will die
‘Otherwise we would all have died.’

Addition of (66) to (64) achieves equal completeness, yet there is no empty position in (66) to license the topic. Aware of this problem, Shi argues further that in such a case one can interpret the topic as a sentential adverbial and then add another adverbial such as naci ‘that time’ to (66) to be anaphoric to the topic. Adding it to (66) produces (67a). It is generally possible to insert a temporal adverbial freely. Even if the temporal adverbial does not occur overtly, an empty one will serve the purpose as well. So one can take (66) as containing an empty resumptive proform anaphoric to the topic, as in (67b):

(67)
a. Nachang huoi, xingkui xiaofangdui lai-de kuai. Buran nacii women dou hui shao-si. Chinese
b. Nachang huoi, xingkui xiaofangdui lai-de kuai. Buran ei women dou hui shao-si.

Pan and Hu (2001, 2002) object that by so doing Shi allows the topic in (64) to be licensed by a null element in a null clause. This is such an extremely powerful means that it makes his hypothesis in (58) unfalsifiable. It has hardly any explanatory power.

subsection.heading: 3.2.3 Related but not coreferential?
subsection.p: Shi's six types of topic structures, each supposedly containing a ‘dangling topic’, do not form an exhaustive list of Chinese-style topic structures. There is at least one more type of topic structure that merits more attention. It is also among the most frequently cited illustrations of Chinese-style topic structures. One example of this type, cited from Chen (1996), appears in Shi (2000: 401) in a paragraph in which he considers the possibility of relativizing topics. But he does not make it clear whether the sentence-initial NP in (68) is also a subject:

(68)
Shuiguo wo zui xihuan chi xiangjiao. Chinese
fruit I most like eat banana
‘(Among) all fruits, I like to eat bananas the most.’

This sentence represents a commonly used topic structure, where the topic is the superordinate term while there is another NP in the comment which is semantically its hyponym. 20 But unlike in the double subject construction, the two semantically related NPs are not adjacent to each other. (68) differs from the double nominative construction and also from any of the topic structures involving ‘dangling topics’. Obviously, shuiguo cannot be taken as a modifier or specifier of wo. It is related to xiangjiao, of course. But the relation is not coreferential. It does not inherit a thematic role from it. Thus it is not compatible with Shi's definition of topic in (58).

To summarize, on the one hand, the so-called Chinese-style topic structures do share some syntactic and semantic properties. On the other hand, they appear in such a variety of constructions that it is hard to reduce each and every one of them to an English-style topic structure or to a structure without a topic.

subsection.heading: 4 Post-subject topic
subsection.p: The canonical word order of Chinese is SVO, as exemplified in (69a). Alongside the topic structure in (69b), in which the object is situated at the front, we also find (69c), where it occurs between the subject and the verb:

(69)
a. Ta du le zheben shu. Chinese
he read ASP this book
‘He read this book.’
b. Zheben shu ta du le.
c. Ta zheben shu du le.

The preposed NP zheben shu in (69c) is known variably as preposed object, shifted object, or post-subject topic, and also as preverbal topic, subtopic, secondary topic, inverted topic, etc., in the literature. Some researchers argue that it is not a topic, but a focus. The two controversial issues with regard to this construction are: (i) how is (69c) syntactically derived, and (ii) what is the nature of the preposed object – a topic or a focus?

subsection.heading: 4.1.1 Double topicalization
subsection.p: Presumably, the sentence in (70c) may be derived by topicalizing both the subject and the object in (70a) in the following manner. The object in (70a) moves to the clause-initial position first, producing (70b), and then the subject moves across the preposed object, producing (70c):

(70)
a. Ta du le zheben shu. Chinese
b. Zheben shui, ta du le ei.
c. Tai zheben shui ej du le ei.
This mechanism is called Double Topic Hypothesis by Ernst and Wang (1995) and Shyu (1995). 21

subsection.heading: 4.1.2 VP adjunction
subsection.p: Ernst and Wang (1995) present evidence against the Double Topicalization Hypothesis in favor of the VP-Adjunction Hypothesis. The latter allows the object to move and adjoin to any segment of the VP. It can account for the following data:

(71)
a. *Yijing Guorong ye ziji feng-hao yifu le. Chinese
already Guorong also self sew clothes ASP
‘Guorong already can sew clothes himself.’
b. Guorong yijing yifu ye ziji feng-hao le.
Guorong already clothes also self sew ASP

The adverb yijing must occur in the VP. Hence the contrast between (71a) and (71b) in grammaticality. If both the object and the subject undergo movement to the front, they should both precede the adverb. The VP-Adjunction Hypothesis, on the other hand, makes the correct prediction, as it allows the object to adjoin freely to a position under the adverb, giving (71b).

subsection.heading: 4.1.3 Substitution movement
subsection.p: Qu (1994), Shyu (1995), and some other researchers maintain that the preposed object undergoes overt A-movement. A-movement is subject to the locality condition. This hypothesis can account for the fact that object preposing, unlike topicalization, never crosses sentence boundaries. The object of the embedded clause can move to the front of the matrix clause, but it cannot be located between the matrix subject and the verb:

(72)
a. Zheben shu, laoshi zhidao [xuesheng du guo e]. Chinese
this book teacher know student read ASP
‘This book, the teacher knows the students have read.’
b. *Laoshi zheben shu zhidao [xuesheng du guo e].
teacher this book know student read ASP

Those who advocate A-movement agree that it is motivated by feature checking but disagree as to which feature or features to check and where. Following Pollock (1989) and Chomsky and Lasnik (1993), Qu (1994) assumes that the object raises to Spec of AgrOP for case and feature (presumably phi-features) checking. It is a substitution movement. Treating the preposed object as a focused NP on a par with those bearing an overt focus marker, Shyu (1995) assumes that it raises to Spec of FP (Focus Projection) to check the focus feature. Similarly, Gasde (1998) hypothesizes the existence of a Focus Phrase within IP, which he calls Focus2 Phrase to distinguish it from the Focus1 Phrase higher up. An object with the feature [+contrastive] can move into the Spec of Focus2P and stay there. Alternatively it can use this position as a medial landing site on the way to the Spec of Focus1P. Zhang (2000) also holds that movement is triggered by focus, though the focus marker is phonetically unrealized. The focus marker, overt or covert, triggers a strong feature and results in object shift to the checking domain. Accusative Case feature is checked along with it.

subsection.heading: 4.1.4 Base generation
subsection.p: There is another construction containing an NP between the subject and the verb, illustrated by (73b), alongside the typical topic structure in (73a). The latter is extensively discussed in Tsao (1990), but not considered by proponents of the movement hypothesis:

(73)
a. Shuiguo ta zui xihuan pingguo. Chinese
fruit he most like apple
‘Speaking of fruit, he likes apple most.’
b. Ta shuiguo zui xihuan pingguo.
he fruit most like apple

The two sentences are equally well-formed and one is the exact paraphrase of the other. The only difference is that the NP semantically related to the one in object position is situated clause-initially in (73a), but between the subject and the verb in (73b). They are both ‘Chinese-styled’, as it were. Once the existence of (73b) is recognized, previous controversies over movement and base generation in topic structures are revived. Since there can be no possible original site for shuiguo in (73b), one is compelled to admit that at least some post-subject NPs are base-generated. It has no Accusative Case feature to check because Accusative Case is assigned to another NP, pingguo, in the postverbal object position. It has no focus feature to check, either, since shuiguo in (73b), just like shuiguo in (73a), is not contrastive. So even if one insists that it originates in a postverbal position somewhere, there is nothing that triggers its movement.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Focus or topic?
subsection.p: In this section we focus our attention on the construction containing a gap bound to an NP between the subject and the verb. Compare:

(74)
a. Ta shi putaojiu bu he. Chinese
he FOC wine not drink
b. Putaojiu ta bu he.
c. Ta putaojiu bu he.

When putaojiu in all three of these sentences is contrastive, researchers all agree that it is an overtly marked focus in (74a) and a topic in (74b). What is controversial is whether the one in (74c) is a focus or a topic.

subsection.heading: 4.2.1 Notion of focus
subsection.p: Ernst and Wang (1995), Shyu (1995), Gasde (1998), and Zhang (2000) call the NP between the subject and the verb ‘focus’ in view of the fact that it is contrastive and is structurally distinctive from the sentence-initial topic. Typologically, some languages designate a syntactic position for focus. A well-known representative is Hungarian. It has a designated preverbal focus position in addition to a topic position. Such languages are called discourse-configurational language in the terminology of Kiss (1995a). 22 The configuration proposed by Shyu (1995), Gasde (1998), and Zhang (2000) for Chinese sentences like (74c) is quite similar to that of Hungarian focus structures exemplified in Kiss (1998). Shyu and Zhang assume that the preverbal NP is a focus with a zero focus marker, and argue that it has the same semantic properties an overtly marked focus possesses.

But the terms ‘topic’ and ‘focus’ are notoriously confusing. Researchers who prefer to call the NP between the subject and the verb ‘topic’ are aware that what Shyu, Gasde, and Zhang call ‘focus’ is conceptually different from ‘identificational focus’ 23 as defined in Kiss (1995a), or ‘kontrast’ in Vallduví and Vilkuna (1998), or ‘operational focus’ in Roberts (1998). 24 Identificational focus is characterized by exhaustive identification of a set of entities given in the context or situation. Identifying some entity or entities means excluding others. In English and Hungarian, identificational focus has the feature complex of [+exhaustive], [+contrastive]. Kiss uses two tests, designed by Szabolcsi (1981b) and Donka Farkas (p.c. to Kiss) respectively, to determine which expressions in English and Hungarian are exhaustively identificational. The same tests can be used to distinguish Chinese expressions that express exhaustive identification and those that do not. The results can show whether the Chinese NP between the subject and the verb is an identificational focus.

subsection.heading: 4.2.2 Diagnostic tests for identificational focus
subsection.p: Szabolcsi's test involves a pair of sentences. The first one contains a focus consisting of two coordinate NPs. The second sentence differs from the first in that one of the NPs has been dropped. If the first sentence does not logically entail the second one, then the focus is exhaustively identificational. As shown by Kiss, the results of the test confirm exhaustive identification of focus in English cleft constructions and their Hungarian counterparts, and disconfirm exhaustive identification in English and Hungarian topic constructions. Xu (2001) adopts the test to distinguish Chinese sentences containing overtly focus-marked NPs, sentence-initial topic NPs, and postverbal NPs:

(75)
a. Ta shi putaojiu he pijiu bu he. Chinese
he FOC wine and beer not drink
‘It is wine and beer that he doesn't drink.’
b. Ta shi putaojiu bu he.
‘It is wine that he doesn't drink.’

(76)
a. Putaojiu he pijiu, ta bu he. Chinese
wine and beer he not drink
‘Wine and beer, he does not drink.’
b. Putaojiu, ta bu he.
‘Wine, he does not drink.’

(77)
a. Ta putaojiu he pijiu bu he. Chinese
he wine and beer not drink
b. Ta putaojiu bu he.

The sentence in (75a) does not logically entail the one in (75b). This shows that a focus-marked expression expresses exhaustive identification. It has the feature complex of [+contrastive], [+exhaustive]. But the sentences in (76b) and (77b) are logical consequences of those in (76a) and (77a) respectively. So, unlike the focus-marked NP in (75), the sentence-initial topic NP in (76) and the NP between the subject and the verb in (77) do not express exhaustive identification. They both have the feature complex of [+contrastive], [−exhaustive]. 25

Donka Farkas's test involves a dialogue, in which the second speaker intends to negate the statement made by the first speaker. If what the first speaker says expresses exhaustive identification, negation sounds natural:

(78)
a. A: Ta shi Putaojiu bu he. Chinese
he FOC wine not drink
‘It is wine that he doesn't drink.’
b. B: Bu, ta pijiu ye bu he.
no he beer also not drink
‘No, he doesn't drink beer, either.’

(79)
a. A: Putaojiu, ta bu he. Chinese
wine he not drink
‘Wine, he does not drink.’
b. B: #Bu, pijiu, ta ye bu he. 26
no beer he also not drink

(80)
a. A: Ta putaojiu, bu he. Chinese
he wine not drink
b. B: #Bu, ta pijiu ye bu he.
no he beer also not drink

The negation of (78a) by (78b) is natural. With the focus marker shi, speaker A uses (78a) to identiify wine as the only thing that the person doesn't drink. If he doesn't drink beer, either, then it is justified for speaker B to use bu to negate the exhaustivity expressed by the focus maker. On the other hand, (79b) and (80b) are not natural negations of (79a) and (80a). Neither (79a) nor (80a) implies that wine is the only thing the person doesn't drink. The propositions expressed in (79b) and (80b) are mere extensions of or additions to the previous statements made by speaker A. The negative particle bu is out of place.

The two tests produce the same results. Both of them show that an NP between the subject and the verb is conceptually similar to a sentence-initial topic, but different from a focus-marked expression. The NP putaojiu is evidently an identificational focus in (74a) but not in (74b), and (74c). In recognition of this difference, some researchers call the one in (74a) ‘focus’ and the one in (74b) or (74c) ‘topic’. One is a major topic and the other is a subtopic or secondary topic. Other researchers prefer to call the one in (74c) ‘focus’, as a mnemonic to distinguish it syntactically from the sentence-initial ‘topic’, without regard to their common feature characterization.

subsection.heading: 5 Appendix
subsection.p: Shi (2000) reopens an important issue and makes a very strong claim about the structure and interpretation of topic constructions in Chinese. If justified, it may be applicable to languages like Japanese and Korean as well, and may deny some characteristic properties of topic-prominent languages. This article has already given rise to controversy among Chinese linguists. The most important response is from Pan and Hu (2001, 2002), but at the time of writing this was not available in published form. This appendix presents the two opposing views in more details for readers interested in the issue, on top of the illustrative discussion in section 3.2.

As has been mentioned, Shi adopts a piecemeal solution. He lists six types of ‘dangling topics’ and argues that in each case either there is a hidden gap or a resumptive pronoun in the comment from which the sentence-initial element originated, or it is not a genuine topic.

subsection.heading: 5.1 Function of wh-words
subsection.p: Shi calls attention to structures in which the clause following the sentence-initial element begins with a wh-word. He points out that shei in (81) is an indefinite pronoun, interpreted as a quantifier corresponding to anyone in English, not an interrogative pronoun corresponding to which person. 27 The quantifier shei can be deleted without affecting the interpretation of the sentence, giving (81b):

(81)
a. Tamen shei dou bu lai. Chinese
they who all not come
‘They (topic), none of them is coming.’
b. Tamen dou bu lai
they all not come
‘None of them is coming.’

Since the pronoun in (81b) is obviously the subject, so is the one in (81a). Shi provides further evidence in support of this analysis. Modal verbs must follow the subject and the modal verb keyi ‘may’ does follow tamen in (82):

(82)
Tamen keyi shei dou bu lai. Chinese
they may who all not come
‘None of them may come.’

Pan and Hu (2001, 2002) contrast (81a) with (83a), an interrogative sentence in which the wh-word must be interpreted as which person, not as anyone. Deleting shei in (83a) would convert the wh-question into a yes/no question, as in (83b):

(83)
a. Tamen, shei hui lai? Chinese
they who will come
‘Which of them will come?’
b. Tamen hui lai?
they will come
‘Will they come?’

If the sentence-initial pronoun in (83a) is also the subject, does the wh-clause shei hui lai function as the predicate just as the idioms in (59) and (60) do? 28 Then why should interrogative clauses and idiomatized clauses be grouped together as exceptional, as against other clauses?

Pan and Hu also question the validity of using the distribution of keyi to locate the subject. They provide a grammatical sentence in which zhe wan fan is an uncontroversial subject and keyi precedes the subject: 29

(84)
Zhe wan fan keyi liangge ren chi. Chinese
this bowl rice may two people eat
‘This bowl of rice may serve two people.’
Since the position of keyi is variable, it cannot be used as a valid test to locate the subject.

subsection.heading: 5.2 Preposition drop
subsection.p: Another type of topic structure discussed in Shi (2000) is exemplified by (85):

(85)
Zhejian shi, ni bu neng guang mafan yige ren. Chinese
this matter you not can only bother one person
‘As for this matter, you cannot just bother one person.’
Shi argues that (85) is derived from (86) by an operation of preposition drop, as some Chinese prepositions can be deleted without changing the meaning of a sentence:

(86)
Wei zhejian shi, ni bu neng guang mafan yige ren. Chinese
for this matter you not can only bother one person
‘For this matter, you cannot just bother one person.’

A prepositional phrase used as an adverbial can occur in other positions of the sentence as well; for instance, within the VP. So the sentence-initial NP in (85), even if taken as a topic, may be analyzed as syntactically related to an unoccupied position in the comment marked by e in (87):
(87) Zhejian shii, ni bu neng ei guang mafan yi-ge ren.
Pan and Hu challenge Shi's hypothesis of preposition drop by providing the following example containing the same preposition, wei:

(88)
a. Wei zhejian shi, zuotian Zhangsan dajia-le. Chinese
for this matter yesterday Zhangsan fight-ASP
‘Zhangsan fought a fight for this matter yesterday.’
b. *Zhejian shi zuotian Zhangsan dajia-le.
this matter yesterday Zhangsan fight ASP

According to their intuitions, the preposition in (88a) cannot be deleted. On the other hand, many sentence-initial NPs cannot take wei or any other preposition. The fact that some of them can is idiosyncratic rather than systematic.

subsection.heading: 5.3 NP predicate
subsection.p: Shi (2000: 395) defines another type of “dangling topic” as consisting of “two sets of NPs but no verb to head the predicate”:

(89)
Na zhong douzi yi jin sanshi kuai qian. Chinese
that kind bean one catty thirty dollar money
‘That kind of beans (topic), one catty is thirty dollars.’

He argues that na zhong douzi in this construction should be analyzed as a subject rather than a topic on two accounts. First, the NP preceding the non-verbal predicate can be indefinite, as exemplified by (90a). Second, it can be preceded by the emphatic marker shi, as exemplified in (90b). In contrast, the topic in a genuine topic structure, like those in (91a) and (91b), cannot be indefinite and resists focus-marking:

(90)
a. Yizhi qinwa sitiao tui. Chinese
one frog four leg
‘A frog (has) four legs.’
b. Shi na zhong douzi yi jin sanshi kuai qian.
be that kind bean one catty thirty dollar money
‘It is that kind of beans that is worth thirty dollars a catty.’

(91)
a. *Yi zhong douzi, wo mai-le. Chinese
a kind bean I bought-ASP
b. *Shi na zhong douzi wo mai-le.
be that kind bean I buy-ASP

It is true that a topic is generally definite. But Pan and Hu wonder why Shi does not simply use sentences structured like (89) to test the definiteness of the topic. If the demonstrative na in (89) is replaced by a numeral yi, the sentence becomes ungrammatical. The difference between (89) and (92) in acceptability straightforwardly confirms the topichood of the sentence-initial NP in (89):

(92)
*Yi zhong douzi yi jin sanshi kuai qian. Chinese
one kind bean one catty thirty dollar money
‘A kind of beans (topic), one catty is thirty dollars.’

Furthermore, they show that a topic does not necessarily exclude the emphatic marker shi even in a sentence containing a gap bound to it. (93) is a typical topic structure that passes Shi's definition in (58):

(93)
Shi na zhong douzi wo mei mai. Chinese
be that kind bean I but buy
‘It is that kind of beans that I didn't buy.’

A topic cannot convey new information and therefore cannot be an informational focus. But shi marks contrastive focus rather than informational focus. In fact, it may mark contrastive topic as well. 30 The distribution of shi cannot be used to distinguish a topic from a subject. Pan and Hu show that evidence is yet to be found to support Shi's claim that the sentence-initial NP in the fifth type of topic structure is not a topic.

subsection.heading: 5.4 AP predicate
subsection.p: Still another type of topic structure with a ‘dangling topic’ discussed in Shi (2000) is represented by (94), cited from Chen (1996), where two NPs are followed by a clause containing an adjective phrase but no verb:

(94)
Wujia Niuyue zui gui. Chinese
price New York most expensive
‘Speaking of the price of things, New York is most expensive.’

Shi argues that the first NP should be analyzed as a subject rather than a topic and that the second NP is a locative adverbial rather than a subject on both semantic and syntactic grounds. Semantically, what is expensive is the price not the city. Syntactically, wujia passes a diagnostic test on subjecthood: a subject precedes adverbials like yiding (certainly) and jingchang (often):

(95)
a. Wujia yiding Niuyue zui gui. Chinese
price certainly New York most expensive
‘The price of things is certainly the highest in New York.’
b. *Yiding wujia niuyue zui gui.
Pan and Hu present (96), in which wujia and Niuyue have switched positions:

(96)
Niuyue yiding wujia zui gui. Chinese
New York certainly price most expensive
‘The price of things is certainly the highest in New York.’

This example is intended to place Shi in a dilemma. His adverbial placement test selects Niuyue, the NP preceding yiding, as the subject. But semantic predication precludes it. Since what is most expensive can only be the price but not the city, the subject should be wujia. Hence an obvious contradiction exists between his syntax and his semantics. In Pan and Hu's analysis of (94), wujia is the topic, and the subject of the comment clause is a headless NP. 31
Pan and Hu (2001, 2002) derive the topic structure in (94) from the following formula:
(97) &lgr;P&lgr;Q&lgr;Z ⊆ things &lgr;x [x∈Z & P(x) & Q(x)], where P(x) = x is Niuyue de Wujia, Q(x) = x is zuigui, Z = wujia.

subsection.heading: 5.5 Double nominative construction
subsection.p: Shi's six types of topic structures with a ‘dangling topic’ do not include the double nominative construction, commonly regarded in the literature as one of the representatives of Chinese-style topic structures. Shi discusses double nominative sentences like (98) in a later section:

(98)
Li Taitai nuer piaoliang. Chinese
Li Mrs. daughter beautiful
‘Mrs. Li's daughter is beautiful.’

The analysis of the Chinese double nominative construction has been controversial since Teng (1974a). An easily available solution is to take the first NP as the modifier of the second one. Schlobinski and Schütze-Coburn (1992), for instance, still analyze the two NPs as a complex NP structure functioning as a subject, thus concluding that Chinese, like German and English, does not possess a double-subject or double-topic construction. 32 What prevents Chinese grammarians from accepting this kind of solution is their awareness of the fact that adverbs, modal words, etc., may be inserted between the two NPs.

Tsao (1990) observes that the so-called double nominative construction is not homogeneous. In some cases, for instance in (99) below, the second NP has become part of a frozen compound, or at least a semi-compound, and therefore not fully productive:

(99)
Wang Taitai tou teng. Chinese
Wang Mrs. head ache
‘Mrs. Wang is having a headache.’
On the basis of Tsao's dichotomy, Shi (2000: 405) assigns the following structural descriptions to (98) and (99) respectively:

(100)
a. [NP [SPEC Li Taitai] [N nuer]] [PRED piaoliang].
b. [NP Wang Taitai] [PRED tou teng].

In (100a) Li Taitai is a possessive NP taking specifier position, and nuer takes head position. Together they function as the subject of the sentence. In (100b) Wang Taitai is the subject, and its predicate is the entire idiom tou teng, which is a clause by itself. 33 Neither (100a) nor (100b) is a topic structure in his view. To prove the structural description he assigns to Li Taitai nuer is correct, he shows that adverbs like feichang cannot intrude into the NP:

(101)
*Li Taitai feichang nuer piaoliang. Chinese
Li Mrs. extremely daughter beautiful
‘Mrs. Li's daughter is extremely beautiful.’

In Tsao's (1990: 141) analysis, Li Taitai is the topic and nuer is the subject in (100a). He takes Wang Taitai as both the topic and the subject in (100b). Tsao (1990: 125) reveals the complexity and unreliability of adverbial tests, as “adverbs are far from a homogeneous class.” The reason why (101) is ungrammatical is not that Li Taitai and nuer cannot be separated, but that feichang and piaoliang cannot be separated. The adverb feichang modifies the adjective piaoliang and must be adjacent to it. Other expressions can appear between Li Taitai and nuer:

(102)
Li Taitai jushuo nuer hen piaoliang. Chinese
Li Mrs. reportedly daughter very beautiful
‘Reportedly Mrs. Li's daughter is beautiful.’
(Lit. *‘Mrs. Li reportedly daughter is beautiful.’)

The occurrence of jushuo is expected if Li Taitai is analyzed as the topic rather than the specifier, and nuer as the subject rather than the head noun. Compare (102) with (103), a less controversial topic structure. In (103), jushuo can also occur between the topic and the subject:

(103)
Zhetiao xianglian, jushuo Wang Taitai bu xihuan. Chinese
this necklace reportedly Wang Mrs. not like
‘Reportedly, this necklace, Mrs. Wang doesn't like.’
More convincing evidence is needed to maintain the claim of the reductionist view stated in (58).

17 When it is used as an adverb, zhuanmen has more than one sense. It is used in the sense of ‘specially’ in (i):

row.entry: ‘Last time I came to see you in passing; this time I came specially to see you.’

subsection.p: But the same word can also be used as an adverb of frequency, somewhat similar in meaning to always, usually, frequently, etc. When it is inserted in (59) and (60), as in (ii) here, it makes sense only when it is interpreted as an adverb of frequency:

row.entry: ‘They always look at each other.’ Not: ‘They specially look at each other.’

subsection.p: Like many other adverbs of frequency, it is a focus-sensitive operator capable of floating for the purpose of marking the scope of focus. Focus is phonologically marked by intonation contour in English but often syntactically realized in Chinese by means of operator float. Compare the following pair:

row.entry: ‘Xiao Zhang always invites Xiao Li to dine out and never dine at home.’
‘It's always Xiao Zhang that invites Xiao Li; Xiao Li never invites Xiao Zhang.’

subsection.p: The adverb zhuanmen can precede the subject if the latter is intended to be focused or to be within the scope of focus, as in (iiib) above. So the word order in (61) merely shows that the sentence-initial pronoun is not within the focus; it is not proof that it is the subject.
